- The strongest option appears to be the Pair of 9s. Let me work through the scoring: both 9s are odd, so each triggers Odd Todd for +31 chips. 6. Final score: 90 × 9 = 810 chips

That falls short of the 1200 target. Let me explore other hand possibilities. A Two Pair would require a second matching pair, but I only have the 9s. For a Flush, I'd need five cards of the same suit—I have at most three in any suit (Clubs: 6, 7, 9; Hearts: K, Q, 9; Spades: J, 3). A Straight is also impossible with my current ranks (3, 6, 7, 9, J, Q, K) since they don't form five consecutive values.

If I play a Pair of 9s with the 7 of Clubs, 3 of Spades, and 6 of Clubs, only the paired 9s count toward the hand type itself. The unpaired cards won't activate the Odd Todd or Ancient Joker effects, so they contribute nothing beyond their base chip values. This confirms my earlier calculation of 810 chips for this configuration.

I should discard and redraw to find a stronger hand. Face cards like Jacks, Kings, and Queens are even-ranked, so they don't benefit from Odd Todd's bonus. I'll prioritize keeping odd-ranked cards and Clubs. Discarding the Jack of Spades, King of Hearts, and Queen of Hearts (positions 1, 3, 4) gives me three new draws that might form a better combination. # Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
select <pack_card_position> <hand_card_position1> <hand_card_position2> ... <hand_card_positionN> - Select a card from the booster pack. The hand card positions may be required depending on if the booster pack card selected needs targets. In 'Mega' booster packs that say 'choose 2 of N', make the selections one at a time. If you intend to select cards 1 and 3 for example, issue a 'select 1' command, then a 'select 2' command, because the 3rd card position will become the second position after selecting the first card.
skip_booster - Skip the remaining selections in the current booster pack.

2. Neptune - Level up Straight Flush (+4 Mult, +40 chips)

- Ancient Joker: X1.5 Mult per Spade card scored

The next blind is the Boss Blind which debuffs all Diamond cards and requires 1,600 chips.

Let me evaluate each option:

1. Mars (Four of a Kind): I haven't played a Four of a Kind yet. Getting four matching cards is difficult and unlikely. This seems like a weak choice.

2. Neptune (Straight Flush): I've played regular Straights successfully, but a Straight Flush requires 5 cards of the same suit in sequential rank, which is much harder to achieve. I haven't played any flushes or straight flushes yet. This seems risky.

3. Pluto (High Card): High Card is the weakest hand type and I haven't played it. Upgrading it only gives +1 Mult and +10 chips. This is not very useful.


None of these upgrades directly benefit the hands I'm actually using—Straight, Two Pair, and Pair are already performing well. Four of a Kind is extremely difficult to assemble, Straight Flush is even more restrictive, and High Card provides minimal value. I'm essentially choosing between three suboptimal options, but Mars offers the best multiplier boost if I somehow manage to assemble four matching cards.

The real question is whether I should spend the $9 at all. I could preserve my funds for more impactful purchases later in the shop rather than investing in a hand type I'm unlikely to construct.

But since I've already committed $4 to this pack, abandoning it now feels wasteful. Neptune stands out as the strongest option here—if I somehow assemble a Straight Flush, the payoff would be significant given my current joker configuration. Mars offers decent value as a backup, though Four of a Kind remains difficult to trigger. Pluto is essentially dead weight.
